parent_formation: Comando Superiore Forze Armate Africa Settentrionale (North Africa Command)

commander.name: Unknown (not documented)
commander.notes: Commander's name not found in available sources for June 1940

75/27 Mod. 06 Field Gun.notes: II & III Gruppi, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment

100/17 Mod. 14 Howitzer.notes: I Gruppo, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment, Skoda-designed

81mm Mod. 35 Mortar.notes: 9 per infantry regiment (LXIII Battaglione Mortai Divisionale)

45mm Mod. 35 Brixia.notes: Light mortar, company level in infantry regiments

65/17 Mod. 13.notes: 4 per infantry regiment, support weapons companies

supply_logistics.supply_status: Good - Metropolitan division permanently stationed in Libya since pre-war period. Well-supplied at Italy's entry into WWII (10 June 1940). Fuel reserves 12 days for limited motor transport, ammunition stocks 22 days for static defense, water adequate at 4L/man/day for garrison operations, food reserves 25 days. Supply base: Benghazi via coastal logistics. Foot-mobile division with animal transport reduces fuel requirements.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal desert (Eastern Cyrenaica) - rocky plateau, escarpments, limited water

subordinate_units.notes: Attached from 1 March 1940, may not be fully integrated by June 1940

tactical_doctrine.role: Static defense of Eastern Cyrenaica sector, manning fortified positions along Egyptian border
special_capabilities: Metropolitan division with full peacetime training
Permanently stationed in Libya since pre-war period
Familiar with local terrain and defensive positions
known_issues: Binary structure (2 regiments) reduces combat power vs. pre-1939 ternary divisions
Dependent on animal transport for much logistics
Very weak anti-tank capability (only 8 x 47mm guns)
No armored fighting vehicles organic to division
Fascist Militia legion integration still incomplete in June 1940
Vulnerable to mobile warfare tactics employed by British in 1940-41
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Long-term desert garrison, equipped with tropical uniforms, experienced in desert logistics and water management, but lacking mechanization for mobile desert operations

special_rules: Desert Garrison: No penalties for desert operations
Limited Mobility: -2 to strategic movement, primarily foot-mobile
Weak AT Defense: -1 vs. armored attacks
Metropolitan Status: Better trained than colonial units, +1 morale vs. colonial divisions
Destroyed 1940-41: Division was destroyed during Operation Compass/Compass follow-on
historical_engagements: Division destroyed in first British offensive into Libya (1941)

source: TM E 30-420: Handbook on Italian Military Forces (August 1943) - Section 51, Figure 5 (Tier 1, 88% confidence)

Comando Supremo: 63a Divisione Fanteria Cirene organizational history (Tier 2, 78% confidence)

Detailed equipment serial numbers and variant specifications not available
validation.notes: Upgraded to 78% confidence through enhanced Tier 1 Italian TO&E sources. 63a Divisione di Fanteria Cirene was a Metropolitan Infantry Division (not Colonial) permanently stationed in Libya pre-war. Personnel 12,169 total calculated from TM E 30-420 Figure 5 (binary division standard: 10,864 + 2-battalion Militia legion: 1,305). Division composition confirmed: 157th LIGURIA Infantry Regiment, 158th LIGURIA Infantry Regiment, 45th CIRENE Artillery Regiment. Binary structure implemented March 1940 reduced regiments from 3 to 2, reducing combat power but increasing administrative efficiency. This was a standard foot-mobile division (NOT autotrasportabile like Brescia/Pavia), with limited motor transport (145 trucks vs. 300+ for motorized divisions). Artillery: 36 guns standard binary allocation (24× 75/27mm, 12× 100/17mm). Division destroyed during British Operation Compass and follow-on offensive (December 1940-February 1941). Supply status good at June 1940 entry into war as long-term garrison division. Weather Q2 1940: Late spring, 16-35°C, moderate conditions before peak summer heat.
validation.data_quality_notes: This TO&E represents 10 June 1940 (Italy's entry into WWII). Division was one of several metropolitan divisions defending Cyrenaica sector. Binary structure (2 infantry regiments vs. pre-1940 ternary 3 regiments) was recent reorganization. Fascist Militia legion attached 1 March 1940 but full integration may have been incomplete by June. Equipment allocations from TM E 30-420 standard binary division tables, adjusted for non-motorized status. Vehicle counts significantly lower than autotrasportabile divisions. Division fate well-documented (destroyed 1940-41) but commander name remains unidentified in available sources.
